THE NEWS-LETTER.
V01. VI.

NOVEMBER 20, 1901.

No, 4.

THOUGHTS FROM THE YALE BI-CENTENNIAL.
N the noble address made by Mr. Justice Brewer a few weeks ago at the Bicentennial of the Founding of Yale University, he said: "It may fairly be
. claimed that Yale was the first educational institution in the world to make
training for service of the public the supreme object of her life and work." In
comparison with other collegiate institutions the statement is doubtless true, and
it is a proud one
to have made for any University, but the idea of an institution
for training young men up to service of the State was no new one in New Haven
Colony. The Puritans felt the need of education as never had man before.
They placed each man directly before his Maker, with no priestly class to which
Intercession could be made, and in the hands of the man was an infallible book,
the 'only rule of faith and practice."
So we find that education was early
sought by the New Englanders. At least, men must be able to read and understand the Scriptures. The chief aim of the Massachusetts men, which aim in
the very words of the act was copied by the men of Connecticut, was to prevent
that "one chiefe project of that old deluder, Sathan, to keepe men from the
Knowledge of the Scriptures." That "learning may not be buried in the grave
of our forefathers in Church and Commonwealth," schools
were established,
and at Newtown, whose name was changed to Cambridge in memory of the
English alma mater of so many of the clergy, a college was set up. At New
Haven, where the settlers were fully as strict as those of Massachusetts, and
much more so than the Connecticut men, we might have expected to find even
more attention given to the religious need, and that the chief purpose of any
college or school there established would have been the training of ministers.
On the contrary, we find that these colonists, under the leadership of Gov.
Theophilus Eaton and Rev. John Davenport, passed a vote within half a dozen
Years of the first settlement, and before the tree stumps could have removed from
the earliest clearings; "For the better training up of youth in this town that,
through God's blessing, they may be fitted for public service hereafter, either
In church or common weale, it is ordered that a free school be set up." This
school was called free, not because it was free from cost to its pupils, but
because in it there were taught those studies which tend to liberalize men's
minds, and free them from ignorance, and it was Davenport's desire that it should
develop into a college. When he removed to Boston some twenty years later,
he made a grant to the trustees "that
the Grammar school or College at New
Haven, already founded and begun, may be provided for, maintained, and continued for the encouragetnent and bringing up of hopeful youths in the lan guages, and other good literature for the public use and service of the country."

5

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Adverse circumstances hindered the establishment of the college for nearly
sixty years from the time when the Town of New Haven expressed the fine
sentiment we have quoted above, and yet the thought was never lost. The
tradition of a college at New Haven lingered, and John Pierpont, Davenport's
son-in-law and successor in the pastorate of the church, was one of the ten
Congregational clergymen of Connecticut who met at the parsonage in Branford, and bringing a few volumes from their scanty libraries, gave "these books
to found a college in this Colony." We are not surprised that the charter of
the "Collegiate School of Connecticut," as the first name was, should contain
the provision that the institution was established that "Youth may be instructed
in the Arts and Sciences, who, through the blessing of Almighty God, may be
fitted for public employment, both in church and civil State," We find the
same note here and almost the same words as we hear in that early vote of the
Town Meeting. In this provision, we see a deep reverence for the Creator, that
conception of a disinterested life which well fitted the followers of Him who
"pleased not himself," and a clear idea of that solidarity of mankind and the
supreme need of the State to have the best energies of its ablest men which in
these latter days are again calling our educated men into public service. Other
institutions might labor for the self culture of their students, but at Yale the
graduates should learn from the very outset that "no man liveth to himself."
During the two centuries which have passed since, the ideal has been nobly
held before Yale men by a succession of consecrated, able, and zealous presidents and professors. Some have failed to live up to that conception, which
has been the basis of the "Yale spirit," but the student life early became
imbued with the feeling that one must work for others. "Yale sand" meant
not so much courage shown for one's own advantage, but an undaunted purpose
to do one's utmost for the College. Nathan Hale's speech has the true ring.
"I only regret that I have but one life to give for my country." William
Walter Phelps, refusing to resign arduous public office, though such refusal
might have prolonged his life, was a more recent example of the devotion of
Yale men to the service of others. Not alone in the United States and not alone
in direct public service has this spirit been shown and this purpose been carried
out. Missionaries in every foreign clime, and professional and business men
everywhere have displayed that same devotion to public employment.
Last month, over half the living graduates of Yale assembled on the
University campus and participated in the finest academic celebration ever
given in any land. It would have been difficult to have matched that Commemoration Day, but the great numbers and the enthusiasm of the alumni,
their devotion to the University, and the seriousness of their purpose were
unparallelled. From the sermon in the Battell Chapel on Sunday morning to
the farewell reception to President Roosevelt on Wednesday evening, a succession of eloquent addresses, of gorgeous processions by night and day, of
varied athletic events, and of fine musical concerts presented a diversified programme filling nearly every moment of the time.
Most impressive of all to many of those who returned, was the great
assemblage of the alumni, some six thousand in number, in an amphitheatre on

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

the campus on Tuesday evening. For over four hours they sang
college songs
and saw tableaux of scenes in the past history of Yale, until, with the
glare of
rockets and singing of the doxology, they dispersed at midnight. To those of
us from Baltimore, it was pleasant to find that three
of the Johns Hopkins
Faculty: President Rernsen, and Professors Gildersleeve and Osier received
honorary degrees and that of the six orations, two were delivered by President
Gilman and. Dr. Welch. It is worthy of note that the Yale influence came to
Baltimore at the very outset of our University's history; for the two men, we
have just named were, respectively, the first President of the University and the
first dean of the Medical
School. President Northrop of the University of
Minnesota, in his address on Yale's influence on the development of the country, paid a most eloquent tribute to President Gilman's educational
career,
referring to him as the originator of the modern system of graduate instruction
in the United States, and the man who had received
more doctorates than any
other Yale graduate. In fact, the influence of Yale on the education of the
country has been extremely great, and, through graduates who have served as
Presidents and professors in other institutions, the Yale ideas have been carried
all over the land. More truly than Virginia, Yale has been a "Mother of
Presidents," for more colleges have had the leadership of Yale men than of the
graduates of any other University, and nearly every prominent University was
organized by a graduate of Yale. Thus the idea of Davenport has been spread
over the land and to many a man in many a college has come the purpose to
devote his best energies to the "public use and service of the country."

BERNARD C. STEINER.
DR. JACOB H. HOLLANDER COMMENDED.

Z

HE high estimation at which the Johns Hopkins University and its Faculty
are held by our country at large is constantly being brought into evidence. This time it is a member of the Faculty, Dr. Jacob H. Hollander,
Whose services to the Government were of such value that the Secretary of War
last week sent the following letter to President Remsen:
"In February, 1900, when the Government of Porto Rico was in need of the best

expert aid attainable for a revision of its system of taxation, I applied to your University
to permit your associate professor of finance, Dr. J. H. Hollander,
to lay aside his customary. duties and come to our assistance. I now wish to acknowledge to the University the
Obligation which the Government of the United States is under for the services rendered
by Dr. Hollander. While his work as special commissioner
was still unfinished the
military government of the island was superseded by civil government under the act of
Congress, and his performance of his duties had been so satisfactory that he was appointed
treasurer of the island by the President. He performed the duties of that office with
fidelity, while bringing to a successful conclusion the work of framing a comprehensive
and adequate system of taxation, which was subsequently adopted by the Legislature, and
15 now in successful operation. Dr. Hollander returns to the performance of his duties in
the University with the good wishes, and the grateful appreciation of all the officers who
have been engaged in the difficult duty of reorganizing the Government of Porto Rico.
ELIH1J ROOT,
Secretary of War."

4

THE NEWS—LETTER.

In this connection it might be well to remark, that whenever there is any
important Government office to be filled, or any scientific phenomena to be
studied, the United States has usually looked to the Johns Hopkins University
for support. The successor to Dr. Hollander has already been chosen, and
once more the important office of Treasurer of Porto Rico is to be filled by the
Johns Hopkins. Dr. William F. Willoughby, a former graduate student of
the University, will succeed Professor Hollander.

JOHNS HOPKINS MUSICAL CLUBS.
HE Johns Hopkins Musical Club assembled last week to have the annual
picture taken. This was done earlier this year than formerly on account
of the new scheme for poster advertising. Arrangements have been completed whereby a half tone cut, 8x11 inches, will be printed in the middle of
the concert posters. It is expected that this will greatly aid in advertising the
clubs, both in their home concert and on the trips.
So far the following concerts have been scheduled: Johns Hopkins Hospital, November 29; Roland Park, December 6; Hannah More, December 13;
Catonsville, December 20, and Christmas Trip, which will probably include
Charleston, W. Va., December 26; Winchester, Va., December 27; Martinsburg,
Va., afternoon of December 27, and Hagerstown, Md., December 28. The
dates for the Annapolis, Baltimore, Bryan Mawr, Washington and Wilmington
concerts have still to be arranged. The Easter trip will be to Old Point Comfort, where the men will lodge in the Hygeia Hotel and dine in the Chamberlin.
This is an improvement over former years, for never before was the excellent
cuisine of the Chamberlin enjoyed for the entire time. It is expected that the
clubs will leave Fortress Monroe Monday, March 30 and go to Richmond, but
this has not been definitely determined upon.
In regard to the clubs themselves little can be said as yet, except that there
are a large number of candidates. The mandolin club still needs a cornet,
'cello and flute, so if any one in the University is adept or otherwise on any of
these instruments there is a vacancy yearning to be filled.
The Glee Clubs will be selected from the following men: First tenors,
Messrs. Eyster, Carver, Humrichouse, Kumane and Cowles; second tenors,
Messrs. Nelson, Wright, Youtz, Beasley, Hale, Stubbs, Houghton; first basses,
Messrs. King, Meyers, Eager (leader); Snowden, Thomas, Hill and Ford;
second basses, Messrs. Sayler, P. K. Gilman, Marshall, Branch, Moss and
Licking. The Banjo Club will be composed of Messrs. Marshall, (leader);
Snowden, Bryan, Baetjer, Lanier, Hendry, Maynard, Mason, Smith and Murkland, banjeaurines, and Messrs. Converse, Cook, Murphy, Hazelhurst, Hill and
Martin. The men on the Mandolin Club are Messrs. Snowden, (leader);
Bryan, Pearre, England, Moulton, Hall,Dochez, Glocker and Cross, mandolins;
Messrs. Converserse, Murphy, Hazelhurst, Martin, Hill, Smith, and Cook,
guitars, and Messrs. Lanier and Nelson, violins.

OUR NEW SONG

t

HE new song which was used for the first time last Saturday in the Western
Maryland game, appears to have struck much favor with the ''rooters.''
The words are by Mr. Walter B. Carver, to the music of "Michael Roy."
Our Alma Mater in Dixie Land.
Come stand together we'll raise a cheer, and wave the black and blue;
We pledge our faith as loyal sons, to Hopkins we'll be true.
We love our college in Dixie Land, our University,
We shout her praise as we march along, so one, two, three!
CHORUS:
Hurrah! Hurray!
A rousing Hullabaloo! rah!
Our Alma Mater in Dixio Laud,
Hurrah for black and blue!
The Hopkins men on the foot-boll field have won a great renown;
They buck the centre, and run the ends, and pull their opponents down.
And if their bodies are black and blue, they're loyal don't you see,
They bear their colors where 'or they go, so one, two, three!
Hurrah! Hurray! Etc.
We play lacrosse and we shoot for goal, we shoot and not in vain;
The score goes up as our foes go down; we win again and again.
Our boys are out for the championship, as ev'ry one may see;
We cheer the fellows that play lacrosse, so one, two, three!
Hurrah! Hurray! Etc.

UNIVERSITY LECTURES.

t

HE series of six lectures on public speaking, which were concluded last
Monday night by Mr. S. A. King, of the University of London, proved
to be a decided success. Mr. King laid particular stress on the technique
of the art, and his manner of procedure plainly attested his thorough knowledge
of the subject. A large class of graduate students derived no little benefit from
the course. In order to demonstrate the artistic side of his theory, Mr. King
gave a recital of selections from the plays of Shakespeare, and the large audience left thoroughly convinced that he knows what he is doing.

The course of lectures which were recently started by Dr. Frederick Lykes
on the general topic, "Literature of the Victorian Era," are progressing finely.
A large number of local teachers are following the work prescribed.

HE appointment of Dr. William F. Willoughby to succeed Dr. J. H. Hollander as treasurer of Porto Rico, gives evidence of the high opinion held
of Hopkins by the governmental authorities at Washington. Not only
was the chief financial position in the island twice filled by Hopkins men, but
even two of the important secondary places were administered by our graduates. Three of our professors were honored at the Yale Bi-Centennial Celebration, and almost every week some newspaper notice attests to the great esteem
felt for the Hopkins by the general educational world.
Why is it that Baltimore responds so conservatively, so slowly to the calls
of the University; why is it that this city seems to appreciate to such a
small degree the immense benefits the presence of a great educational
center brings a city? Is it because the magnitude of the University's work is
so extensive that it overtowers the city, and consequently causes an unbalanced
perspective? At least, the fact remains that the Baltimore public does not seem
to be able, or does not want to be able, to grasp the full value of our University which a comparative study at a distance never fails to demonstrate.
Whereas Hopkins is honored by having inside its walls men from all parts of
the globe who have come to study in the University, whose fame extends everywhere, our own State does not even think us worthy of enough assistance to
help keep up the reputation so gloriously won. It is said that the million
dollars required before possession of the Homewood Estate is given the University authorities has almost been raised. "Almost," but after nine months
anxious waiting, it seems rather dispiriting not to be able to say "completely"
raised. Baltimore and Maryland are certainly living up to their reputation for

t

conservatism.

THE NEWS—LETTER. -

'7

T IS encouraging to note the increased enthusiasm among the undergraduate
body, and especially among the freshmen class. This enthusiasm is
manifesting itself in the "rooting," for, at last, the "Hopkins lads" seem
to be awakening to a sense of their duty, and are making a "joyful noise." Even
if we have not an undergraduate department consisting of a thousand or so men,
it is perfectly possible for the men we have to organize and do some very effective "rooting
." and we rejoice to see that such is being done. On our Haverford
and on our Wilmington trip our band of "rooters" was very small, indeed, but
what was lacking in numbers was made up by enthusiasm, and the handful of
men made as much noise as fifty.
We still have St. Johns and University of Maryland to play; "rooters,"
come out in a body, and "root" your very hardest.
If every man would buy a small megaphone, at a trifling cost, the effect
produced at these two games would be prodigious. Every one present would
know that Hopkins was out for business then, and the rooting would be most
encouraging.

3

AMONG THE COLLEGES.

Z

HE Minstrel Club of Lehigh will probably give a performance in
Washington on Thanksgiving Day.

Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" has been selected as the play to be
Presented by the Smith College Senior Dramatics this year.
During the summer, $8,000 was expended in refitting the Yale gymnasium.
The Juniors at the University of California are going to raise $2,000 as a
loan Fund.
Princeton may go to the Pacific Coast during the Christmas holidays to play
the University of California.
A Student Union has been organized at Harvard, with a membership of
2,500. Its object is social intercourse and recreation.
The Princeton base ball association cleared $4,596 last season.
Six thousand Yale graduates and about 150 college presidents are said to
have been in New Haven, for the bi-centennial celebration of Yale.
The President of the University of Illinois has issued an address to the
student body on the subject of hazing, which is said to be very severe at Illinois. The president stated that hazing, and certain other college customs,
such as painting the college buildings, and the posting of personal bulletins
had to be stopped.
The Yale faculty has recently provided that every student shall be allowed
to take thirty cuts a year without penalty. It also decided that exceptional
regularity in attendance at recitations may diminish the number of recitation
hours a year in a course from sixty to fifty-eight. This arrangement will allow
candidates for the athletic teams to take a large number of cuts to make up the
deficiency after the close of the athletic season.

X-PRESIDNT D. C. OILMAN has under preparation several articles for
Scribner's Magazine on his recollections of the last twenty-five years.
Dr. Gilman will treat of the advance in intellectual, educational, and
scientific knowledge, as it has come under his observation at Hopkins and
abroad. No one is more fitted to undertake such a series of recollections, and
their publication is awaited with much interest.

e

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees for November, the following
appointments were made: Rev. Theo. C. Foote, of Clinton, 0., to the W. S.
Rayner fellowship in Semitic languages; E. P. Hyde, of Baltimore, to the fellowship in physics; George O. Berg to the fellowship in Greek, succeeding Dr.
Roscoe Guernsey, who is made instructor in Latin; Dr. W. H. Lewis, of the
Medical School, to the instructorship in anatomy.
President Remsen reported that Mrs. Lucy J. Woods, of Jamaica Plains,
Mass., mother of Prof. R. W. Woods, had given $1,000 for the purpose of purchasing new and approved apparatus for the physical laboratory.
The University has received a notice of the Fifteenth Annual Convention
of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and
Maryland. The meeting will take place on November 29 and 30, at Syracuse
University, Many important subjects will be discussed, among them such
timely topics as the executive system in college courses, and the freedom of
speech to educators.
Dr. Harry T. Marshall, of the Medical School, has been selected for the
foreign fellowship of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. The board
of directors, of which Dr. Welsh is president, decided at their last meeting in
New York that the income of the $200,000 fund was to be expended in maintaining 19 fellows, 18 of whom are to work in various American laboratories
and one abroad. Dr. Marshall is already at his post, which is Professor Ehrlich's laboratory in Germany. Each fellowship is for one year, during which
time the incumbent is to do original work and send his report to the Board,
with the view of having it published.
Dr. Richard T. Ely, director of the School of Economics and Political
Science, University of Wisconsin, who was associate professor of Political
Economy at Hopkins, 1887-92, has accepted an invitation to deliver the principal address at a meeting to commemorate the life and services of the late Dr.
Herbert B. Adams, The date of the meeting is uncertain.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

9

The Johns Hopkins Hospital Historical Society held its first meeting for
the year on Monday night, November 11, in the Assembly Rooms of the
Hospital. Papers were read by Dr. John Turner, Jr., on "Ancient
Anatomists," and by Dr. E. F. Cordell on "The Medicine and Doctors of
Juvenal." Dr. Howard A. Kelly is the president of this Society.
Drs. Thomas McCrea and Guy L. Hunner, of the Hospital Medical Society
exhibited some interesting cases at a recent meeting at the Hospital.
The Major Biology Class had an exciting hunt for "Medusae," otherwise
known as jelly fish, last Tuesday. The members of this course heartily endorse this method of studying biology, even though no specimens are found.
The whole class, under the paternal care of Dr. Grave, who paid the carfare,
went to Fort McHenry, and there spent the afternoon in mild forms of recreation such as rowing heavy scows and grasping at imaginary medusae.
The inventory of the late Dr. Herbert B. Adams' personal estate showed
the amount to be $45,244.15, about $30.000 of which is in bonds. By his will,
Dr. Adams made the University residuary legatee of his estate. After various
bequests are made, the University will realize more than $30,000, which, by the
donor's request, will become a Herbert B. Adams Fund, the income to be
devoted to the advancement of history, political science, and education.
Mr. W. H. Buckler has presented to the University an autograph letter of
Benjamin Franklin, written from London to a friend in Florence. The letter
may be seen beneath the picture of Franklin in second floor of the physical
laboratory.
Dr. Geo. Dobbin Brown,Ph.D.in English and Literature last June, has been
appointed to temporarily fill the position of Dr. Tupper, professor of English
Literature in the University of Vermont. Professor Tupper is spending a year
in study at Berlin and Munich.
At the meeting of the Charity Organization Society, Monday of last week.
Dr. D. C. Gilman was elected president of the society. President Remsen and
Dr. Hollander were elected members of the board of governors.

STUDENT NOTES.
HE settee given to the trophy room by the class of 1901 has already shown
its value in bringing comfort to the University "loafing" room. Just
such a thing was needed to add some degree of warmth and coziness to
the room, which despite the hard seats, has always proved the best drawing
card in the University. Thanks are due the senior class for what is easily the
best thing so far given to the trophy-room, and on behalf of the class to the
committee which had such hard work selecting the gift. The committee consisted of J. R. Pels, chairman; G. Sisco, R. Sharretts, F. L. Guggenheimer, L.
C. Murphy.

Z

10

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Junior class is already considering the nature of their gift. Though
nothing definite has yet been decided upon, rumors are floating around in profusion. Everything, including leather upholstered arm chairs and a piano, has
been mentioned, with odds in favor of the chairs.
In the Senate, the ministry has failed, and Mr. S. Wolman, leader of the
opposition, is now in control of the government. The following administrative
officers have been chosen by Mr. Wolman to represent the opposition on the
floor; W. Kirk, Leader pro tem.; H. G. Dew, Secretary; Thomas C. Pinkerton,
Sergeant-at-Arms. Wednesday's debate was on the advisability of expelling all
anarchists from this country as the best means of eradicating anarchy.
The Musical Clubs have had their annual picture taken. As this year the
picture will be used on 1500 posters, extra care was employed to get a satisfactory group.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE Week of Prayer for young men was observed last week with daily
service in Levering Hall, from 1 to 1.20. Monday, Dr. Vincent spoke
on "The Reciprocal Relation of Learning to Religion;" Tuesday, Dr.
Greene, on "The Danger of Spiritual Neglect;" Wednesday, Dr. Henry Wood,
on "True Christian Realism;" Thursday, Dr. Brush, on "Honesty;" Friday,
Dr. Steiner, on "Overcoming."
The week of service was opened on Sunday by an inspiring address from
Rev. Oliver Huckel, on "Spiritual Realities."
The average attendance for the week was 25.
Mr. Robert E. Speer is expected to address a mass meeting of students on
Sunday, January 19th. Further notice will be given later.
The regular monthly meeting of the Executive Council was held Wednesday, November 13, at 5 P. M. About thirty new members were elected.
The State University of Iowa and McGill University are both campaigning
for Association buildings.

HOPKINS, 27. DELAWARE, 0.
ATURDAY, November 9th, the Hopkins team covered itself with laurels
and caused many loyal hearts to beat faster, when she downed the Delaware College eleven in Wilmington by a score of 27 to 0. Too much
cannot be said in praise of the magnificent work done by the team as a whole
and by the individual players. And, add to this the fact that IIaverford, which
defeated our boys only a week previous in the hottest contest of the season by a
score of only 5 to 0, had been defeated by the Delaware lads earlier in the
season, every Hopkins "rooter" has just cause to be proud of the men who
wear the Black and Blue.
To be sure, Delaware was seriously weakened by the absence of Huxley,
their regular captain, and a few more of their men, but where were Garwood
and the other Hopkins men who had done so nobly in the Haverford game?
Everything taken into consideration, the teams were well matched both in
regard to weight and science, and all that our boys have achieved, they have
done on their own merits and to them all the praise is due.
For Hopkins, it would be difficult to single out one man who did more than
another for the success of the team. The backs played the game, and Gillespie
and Houghton went around the ends each time for a gain. Only twice during
the game was the oval in the possession of their opponents. For Delaware,
Lawton kicked well, and gained much time by the clever placing of the ball in
the second half; Cann, at right end, showed remarkable skill; Wilson did
excellent work back of the line, and Marshall, a new man, made several
beautiful tackles.
In the first half, after eight minutes of play, Gillespie circled the right end
for a touchdown, and in the remaining ten minutes of play, the 'varsity took a
brace, and before the referee's whistle blew, Sayler, Gillespie and Faris went
over the goal line for three more touchdowns.
Hopkins took the kick-off at the beginning of the game, and Blanck downed
the man after a short run. Lawton hit the line without effect, and Cooper went
around right end for eight yards. No more ground could be gained, and Cann

g

12

THE NEWS—LETTER.

punted. Upon lining up, Sayler hit right tackle for five yards. Faris made a
plunge through the opposite tackle for 15 yards, and Gillespie and Houghton
made large gains on successive end-around-end runs.
The ball went steadily down the field, and Gillespie went around the end
for the first touchdown. Sayler failed to kick goal. On the second kick-off Bernheim caught the ball and made a pretty run before going down. Gillespie,
Faris, and Sayler made end runs of 12, 10 and 18 yards, repectively. End plays
by the backs and ends came off in quick succession, and Faris circled right end
for the second touchdown. Sayler did not kick goal.
On the next kick-off Blanck downed the ball, and the first play saw Faris
circle right end for eighteen yards. Houghton then showed his ability as a
sprinter. He was given the ball on the end-around-end play, and made a beautiful run of 40 yards. Gillespie again circled right end for 20 yards and a
touchdown. Sayler kicked goal.
On the line-up after the kick off, Gillespie repeated Houghton's trick by
rounding the opposite end for 40 yards. Sayler and Faris did not fail in a
single instance to make heavy gains through the line, and Sayler increased the
score to 22 points by hitting right tackle for a fourth touchdown. Only a few
more minutes of the half remained, but Blanck, Faris and Gillespie managed to
advance the ball about 32 yards before time was called.
In the second half, Delaware took a decided brace and the Hopkins men
were unable to secure more than one more touchdown. Lawton gained much time
by cleverly kicking the ball out of bounds each time it came into Delaware's possession. The game ended with the ball in Delaware's 35-yard line.

WESTERN MARYLAND, 0.

N a bard-fought contest, Saturday afternoon, IIopkins gave the annual
exhibition of beating Western Maryland. When the game started the
.
Westminster lads were confident that victory was theirs, and, indeed, for a
time the struggle was so fierce, that it seemed as if one team was as good as the
other, if not better.
. Western Maryland kicked off to Houghton, who advanced the ball to Hopkins 30 yard line. The Black and Blue now began to hammer their opponents'
line, and by fierce plunges through the opposite guards advanced the pigskin
15 yards. The Farmers now took a brace, and the line held like a stone wall,
so the ball went over. The Hopkinsonians in turn made a solid stand against
their opponents, and after a trifling gain by Western Maryland, again recovered
the oval, but lost it on a fumble.
.
The Westminster lads now tried some end runs, but in almost every
instance the runner was nailed in his tracks, so that the ball went over on downs.
Sayler was now sent around end for a gain of 10 yards, and Blanck in a similar

3

manner added 5 other yards hereto.
Western Maryland, still confident, however, allowed the Black and Blue to
make no further gains and the pigskins was lost on downs.
The Farmers slowly but steadily pushed the oval back over most of the
ground gained by Hopkins, but were interrupted by Sayler and Garwood, who
by brilliant tackling, caused Western Maryland to lose on downs.
The first half ended with the ball on Hopkins' 30 yard line, where Houghton
carried it on the kick-off, both teams having seesawed up and down in a space
of about 20 yards duringthe entire half.
In the second half, Sayler kicked off for Hopkins, and Western Maryland
brought the oval to her 25 yard line, and then failing to gain the required distance, punted. Hopkins now began to play ball in dead earnest; Blanck hit
the line for 7 yards, and Riggs followed with 8 more. Houghton now got
around the end at a beautiful rate, but strained his ankle, and was replaced by
Sharretts. Sayler again circled the ends for 20 yards, and Sharretts was shoved
through the line for an additional 8. The Black and Blue now had the ball
Within 5 yards of a touchdown, but there they stuck, and the oval was lost on
downs. Not discouraged by this, however, Hopkins soon forced her opponents
to kick, and with a beautiful end run of 20 yards by Sayler, the lost territory
was well nigh recovered. With two more line plunges, the pigskin rested on
the 3 yard line, and Riggs did the mark. Sayler then kicked a goal.
Western Maryland now kicked off and Hopkins began to pound the
Farmer's line a terrible rate, the latter being unable to hold together in any
Shape whatever. So by long gains through the line, and end runs, the Black
and Blue soon scored on her touchdown, failing to kick goal, however.
Western Maryland again kicked off, and Hopkins was well on her way to her
touchdown when time was called, with the ball on Western Maryland's 25 yard
line.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Everyone is satisfied with the work of the team, and all are confident that
the same team can rub it into St. John's next Saturday. Garwood's work is
well nigh equal to that of Butler, whose style of play last year was so phenomenal. Sayler should he complimented for his effective work this season, especially in Saturday's game, and what Hill did to Western Maryland's star—
Roberts—was "enough." Coach Dickson remarked after the game, that the
fellows helped each other wonderfully. A little more practice in catching
punts, and we'll have a star team. The rooting, led by Grasty, was the best
heard this season, and the NEWS-LETTER hopes that all students in the
University will join the ranks next Saturday to cheer the Black and Blue on to
victory.

OUR SCRUB TEAM.

C

APTAIN GILLESPIE, of the 'varsity eleven, is to be congratulated for his
wisdom in appointing a captain of the scrub team, and Captain Winternitz also deserves a vote of thanks for the hearty manner in which he has
taken hold of matters and pushed his eleven forward. While the 'varsity was
administering a severe defeat to Delaware College last Saturday one week ago,
the scrubs were playing their first game against Dunham's Preparatory School.
Captain Winternitz had not yet completely organized the team, and the lack of
systematic play and unity lost the game by the score of 6 to 0. In the contest
against Marston's Preparatory School last Friday, however, the benefit of a
week's practice was plainly shown. For about five minutes in the first half,
Marston's held her own, and possibly a little more, but then the scrubs got
together, and from that moment on there was certainly "somethin' doin'."
Dickey, Pearre, and Plaggemeyer hit the line in great fashion, and little IIazlehurst toddled around the end for comfortable gains. Dickey made the star play
of the game, by catching the ball from the kick-off and running through the

J

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

entire Marston eleven for a touchdown. Toward the end of the game the
scrubs worked together in great style, and it was this fast, concerted action
which gave them the victory by a score of 16 to 0. The work of several freshmen was conspicuous, and they promise to put up a hard fight when the annual
class game with the Juniors comes off. The scrubs usually line up as follows:
Hazlehurst, 1. e.; Riley, 1. t.; Erlanger, 1. g.; Marshall, c.; Ward, r. g.; Custis,
r. t.; Parsons, r. e.; Winternitz (captain) q. b.; Dickey, Pearre, 1. h. b.; Smith,
r. h. b.; Plaggerneyer, f. b.
The organization of a scrub team is a wise innovation in more ways than
one. In the first place, it adds strength and system to the team which is
depended upon to give the 'varsity practice; secondly, it brings out a great
many men who would not come out because of their inability to make the
'varsity; and thirdly, it arouses additional spirit among the freshmen, several
of whom are on the team. All these results tend to increase our chances of
winning the inter collegiate championship in the game with St. John's College
Saturday afternoon, It is every man's sacred duty to be on hand that day with
a strong pair of lungs in good working order.

NOVEMBER 20, 1901.

No, 4.

THOUGHTS FROM THE YALE BI-CENTENNIAL.
N the noble address made by Mr. Justice Brewer a few weeks ago at the Bicentennial of the Founding of Yale University, he said: "It may fairly be
. claimed that Yale was the first educational institution in the world to make
training for service of the public the supreme object of her life and work." In
comparison with other collegiate institutions the statement is doubtless true, and
it is a proud one
to have made for any University, but the idea of an institution
for training young men up to service of the State was no new one in New Haven
Colony. The Puritans felt the need of education as never had man before.
They placed each man directly before his Maker, with no priestly class to which
Intercession could be made, and in the hands of the man was an infallible book,
the 'only rule of faith and practice."
So we find that education was early
sought by the New Englanders. At least, men must be able to read and understand the Scriptures. The chief aim of the Massachusetts men, which aim in
the very words of the act was copied by the men of Connecticut, was to prevent
that "one chiefe project of that old deluder, Sathan, to keepe men from the
Knowledge of the Scriptures." That "learning may not be buried in the grave
of our forefathers in Church and Commonwealth," schools
were established,
and at Newtown, whose name was changed to Cambridge in memory of the
English alma mater of so many of the clergy, a college was set up. At New
Haven, where the settlers were fully as strict as those of Massachusetts, and
much more so than the Connecticut men, we might have expected to find even
more attention given to the religious need, and that the chief purpose of any
college or school there established would have been the training of ministers.
On the contrary, we find that these colonists, under the leadership of Gov.
Theophilus Eaton and Rev. John Davenport, passed a vote within half a dozen
Years of the first settlement, and before the tree stumps could have removed from
the earliest clearings; "For the better training up of youth in this town that,
through God's blessing, they may be fitted for public service hereafter, either
In church or common weale, it is ordered that a free school be set up." This
school was called free, not because it was free from cost to its pupils, but
because in it there were taught those studies which tend to liberalize men's
minds, and free them from ignorance, and it was Davenport's desire that it should
develop into a college. When he removed to Boston some twenty years later,
he made a grant to the trustees "that
the Grammar school or College at New
Haven, already founded and begun, may be provided for, maintained, and continued for the encouragetnent and bringing up of hopeful youths in the lan guages, and other good literature for the public use and service of the country."

5

2

THE NEWS-LETTER.

Adverse circumstances hindered the establishment of the college for nearly
sixty years from the time when the Town of New Haven expressed the fine
sentiment we have quoted above, and yet the thought was never lost. The
tradition of a college at New Haven lingered, and John Pierpont, Davenport's
son-in-law and successor in the pastorate of the church, was one of the ten
Congregational clergymen of Connecticut who met at the parsonage in Branford, and bringing a few volumes from their scanty libraries, gave "these books
to found a college in this Colony." We are not surprised that the charter of
the "Collegiate School of Connecticut," as the first name was, should contain
the provision that the institution was established that "Youth may be instructed
in the Arts and Sciences, who, through the blessing of Almighty God, may be
fitted for public employment, both in church and civil State," We find the
same note here and almost the same words as we hear in that early vote of the
Town Meeting. In this provision, we see a deep reverence for the Creator, that
conception of a disinterested life which well fitted the followers of Him who
"pleased not himself," and a clear idea of that solidarity of mankind and the
supreme need of the State to have the best energies of its ablest men which in
these latter days are again calling our educated men into public service. Other
institutions might labor for the self culture of their students, but at Yale the
graduates should learn from the very outset that "no man liveth to himself."
During the two centuries which have passed since, the ideal has been nobly
held before Yale men by a succession of consecrated, able, and zealous presidents and professors. Some have failed to live up to that conception, which
has been the basis of the "Yale spirit," but the student life early became
imbued with the feeling that one must work for others. "Yale sand" meant
not so much courage shown for one's own advantage, but an undaunted purpose
to do one's utmost for the College. Nathan Hale's speech has the true ring.
"I only regret that I have but one life to give for my country." William
Walter Phelps, refusing to resign arduous public office, though such refusal
might have prolonged his life, was a more recent example of the devotion of
Yale men to the service of others. Not alone in the United States and not alone
in direct public service has this spirit been shown and this purpose been carried
out. Missionaries in every foreign clime, and professional and business men
everywhere have displayed that same devotion to public employment.
Last month, over half the living graduates of Yale assembled on the
University campus and participated in the finest academic celebration ever
given in any land. It would have been difficult to have matched that Commemoration Day, but the great numbers and the enthusiasm of the alumni,
their devotion to the University, and the seriousness of their purpose were
unparallelled. From the sermon in the Battell Chapel on Sunday morning to
the farewell reception to President Roosevelt on Wednesday evening, a succession of eloquent addresses, of gorgeous processions by night and day, of
varied athletic events, and of fine musical concerts presented a diversified programme filling nearly every moment of the time.
Most impressive of all to many of those who returned, was the great
assemblage of the alumni, some six thousand in number, in an amphitheatre on

THE NEWS-LETTER.

3

the campus on Tuesday evening. For over four hours they sang
college songs
and saw tableaux of scenes in the past history of Yale, until, with the
glare of
rockets and singing of the doxology, they dispersed at midnight. To those of
us from Baltimore, it was pleasant to find that three
of the Johns Hopkins
Faculty: President Rernsen, and Professors Gildersleeve and Osier received
honorary degrees and that of the six orations, two were delivered by President
Gilman and. Dr. Welch. It is worthy of note that the Yale influence came to
Baltimore at the very outset of our University's history; for the two men, we
have just named were, respectively, the first President of the University and the
first dean of the Medical
School. President Northrop of the University of
Minnesota, in his address on Yale's influence on the development of the country, paid a most eloquent tribute to President Gilman's educational
career,
referring to him as the originator of the modern system of graduate instruction
in the United States, and the man who had received
more doctorates than any
other Yale graduate. In fact, the influence of Yale on the education of the
country has been extremely great, and, through graduates who have served as
Presidents and professors in other institutions, the Yale ideas have been carried
all over the land. More truly than Virginia, Yale has been a "Mother of
Presidents," for more colleges have had the leadership of Yale men than of the
graduates of any other University, and nearly every prominent University was
organized by a graduate of Yale. Thus the idea of Davenport has been spread
over the land and to many a man in many a college has come the purpose to
devote his best energies to the "public use and service of the country."

DR. JACOB H. HOLLANDER COMMENDED.

HE high estimation at which the Johns Hopkins University and its Faculty
are held by our country at large is constantly being brought into evidence. This time it is a member of the Faculty, Dr. Jacob H. Hollander,
Whose services to the Government were of such value that the Secretary of War
last week sent the following letter to President Remsen:
"In February, 1900, when the Government of Porto Rico was in need of the best

expert aid attainable for a revision of its system of taxation, I applied to your University
to permit your associate professor of finance, Dr. J. H. Hollander,
to lay aside his customary. duties and come to our assistance. I now wish to acknowledge to the University the
Obligation which the Government of the United States is under for the services rendered
by Dr. Hollander. While his work as special commissioner
was still unfinished the
military government of the island was superseded by civil government under the act of
Congress, and his performance of his duties had been so satisfactory that he was appointed
treasurer of the island by the President. He performed the duties of that office with
fidelity, while bringing to a successful conclusion the work of framing a comprehensive
and adequate system of taxation, which was subsequently adopted by the Legislature, and
15 now in successful operation. Dr. Hollander returns to the performance of his duties in
the University with the good wishes, and the grateful appreciation of all the officers who
have been engaged in the difficult duty of reorganizing the Government of Porto Rico.
ELIH1J ROOT,
Secretary of War."

THE NEWS—LETTER.

In this connection it might be well to remark, that whenever there is any
important Government office to be filled, or any scientific phenomena to be
studied, the United States has usually looked to the Johns Hopkins University
for support. The successor to Dr. Hollander has already been chosen, and
once more the important office of Treasurer of Porto Rico is to be filled by the
Johns Hopkins. Dr. William F. Willoughby, a former graduate student of
the University, will succeed Professor Hollander.

JOHNS HOPKINS MUSICAL CLUBS.
HE Johns Hopkins Musical Club assembled last week to have the annual
picture taken. This was done earlier this year than formerly on account
of the new scheme for poster advertising. Arrangements have been completed whereby a half tone cut, 8x11 inches, will be printed in the middle of
the concert posters. It is expected that this will greatly aid in advertising the
clubs, both in their home concert and on the trips.
So far the following concerts have been scheduled: Johns Hopkins Hospital, November 29; Roland Park, December 6; Hannah More, December 13;
Catonsville, December 20, and Christmas Trip, which will probably include
Charleston, W. Va., December 26; Winchester, Va., December 27; Martinsburg,
Va., afternoon of December 27, and Hagerstown, Md., December 28. The
dates for the Annapolis, Baltimore, Bryan Mawr, Washington and Wilmington
concerts have still to be arranged. The Easter trip will be to Old Point Comfort, where the men will lodge in the Hygeia Hotel and dine in the Chamberlin.
This is an improvement over former years, for never before was the excellent
cuisine of the Chamberlin enjoyed for the entire time. It is expected that the
clubs will leave Fortress Monroe Monday, March 30 and go to Richmond, but
this has not been definitely determined upon.
In regard to the clubs themselves little can be said as yet, except that there
are a large number of candidates. The mandolin club still needs a cornet,
'cello and flute, so if any one in the University is adept or otherwise on any of
these instruments there is a vacancy yearning to be filled.
The Glee Clubs will be selected from the following men: First tenors,
Messrs. Eyster, Carver, Humrichouse, Kumane and Cowles; second tenors,
Messrs. Nelson, Wright, Youtz, Beasley, Hale, Stubbs, Houghton; first basses,
Messrs. King, Meyers, Eager (leader); Snowden, Thomas, Hill and Ford;
second basses, Messrs. Sayler, P. K. Gilman, Marshall, Branch, Moss and
Licking. The Banjo Club will be composed of Messrs. Marshall, (leader);
Snowden, Bryan, Baetjer, Lanier, Hendry, Maynard, Mason, Smith and Murkland, banjeaurines, and Messrs. Converse, Cook, Murphy, Hazelhurst, Hill and
Martin. The men on the Mandolin Club are Messrs. Snowden, (leader);
Bryan, Pearre, England, Moulton, Hall,Dochez, Glocker and Cross, mandolins;
Messrs. Converserse, Murphy, Hazelhurst, Martin, Hill, Smith, and Cook,
guitars, and Messrs. Lanier and Nelson, violins.

UNIVERSITY LECTURES.

t

HE series of six lectures on public speaking, which were concluded last
Monday night by Mr. S. A. King, of the University of London, proved
to be a decided success. Mr. King laid particular stress on the technique
of the art, and his manner of procedure plainly attested his thorough knowledge
of the subject. A large class of graduate students derived no little benefit from
the course. In order to demonstrate the artistic side of his theory, Mr. King
gave a recital of selections from the plays of Shakespeare, and the large audience left thoroughly convinced that he knows what he is doing.

The course of lectures which were recently started by Dr. Frederick Lykes
on the general topic, "Literature of the Victorian Era," are progressing finely.
A large number of local teachers are following the work prescribed.

HE appointment of Dr. William F. Willoughby to succeed Dr. J. H. Hollander as treasurer of Porto Rico, gives evidence of the high opinion held
of Hopkins by the governmental authorities at Washington. Not only
was the chief financial position in the island twice filled by Hopkins men, but
even two of the important secondary places were administered by our graduates. Three of our professors were honored at the Yale Bi-Centennial Celebration, and almost every week some newspaper notice attests to the great esteem
felt for the Hopkins by the general educational world.
Why is it that Baltimore responds so conservatively, so slowly to the calls
of the University; why is it that this city seems to appreciate to such a
small degree the immense benefits the presence of a great educational
center brings a city? Is it because the magnitude of the University's work is
so extensive that it overtowers the city, and consequently causes an unbalanced
perspective? At least, the fact remains that the Baltimore public does not seem
to be able, or does not want to be able, to grasp the full value of our University which a comparative study at a distance never fails to demonstrate.
Whereas Hopkins is honored by having inside its walls men from all parts of
the globe who have come to study in the University, whose fame extends everywhere, our own State does not even think us worthy of enough assistance to
help keep up the reputation so gloriously won. It is said that the million
dollars required before possession of the Homewood Estate is given the University authorities has almost been raised. "Almost," but after nine months
anxious waiting, it seems rather dispiriting not to be able to say "completely"
raised. Baltimore and Maryland are certainly living up to their reputation for

t

conservatism.

T IS encouraging to note the increased enthusiasm among the undergraduate
body, and especially among the freshmen class. This enthusiasm is
manifesting itself in the "rooting," for, at last, the "Hopkins lads" seem
to be awakening to a sense of their duty, and are making a "joyful noise." Even
if we have not an undergraduate department consisting of a thousand or so men,
it is perfectly possible for the men we have to organize and do some very effective "rooting
." and we rejoice to see that such is being done. On our Haverford
and on our Wilmington trip our band of "rooters" was very small, indeed, but
what was lacking in numbers was made up by enthusiasm, and the handful of
men made as much noise as fifty.
We still have St. Johns and University of Maryland to play; "rooters,"
come out in a body, and "root" your very hardest.
If every man would buy a small megaphone, at a trifling cost, the effect
produced at these two games would be prodigious. Every one present would
know that Hopkins was out for business then, and the rooting would be most
encouraging.

HE Minstrel Club of Lehigh will probably give a performance in
Washington on Thanksgiving Day.

Shakespeare's "Romeo and Juliet" has been selected as the play to be
Presented by the Smith College Senior Dramatics this year.
During the summer, $8,000 was expended in refitting the Yale gymnasium.
The Juniors at the University of California are going to raise $2,000 as a
loan Fund.
Princeton may go to the Pacific Coast during the Christmas holidays to play
the University of California.
A Student Union has been organized at Harvard, with a membership of
2,500. Its object is social intercourse and recreation.
The Princeton base ball association cleared $4,596 last season.
Six thousand Yale graduates and about 150 college presidents are said to
have been in New Haven, for the bi-centennial celebration of Yale.
The President of the University of Illinois has issued an address to the
student body on the subject of hazing, which is said to be very severe at Illinois. The president stated that hazing, and certain other college customs,
such as painting the college buildings, and the posting of personal bulletins
had to be stopped.
The Yale faculty has recently provided that every student shall be allowed
to take thirty cuts a year without penalty. It also decided that exceptional
regularity in attendance at recitations may diminish the number of recitation
hours a year in a course from sixty to fifty-eight. This arrangement will allow
candidates for the athletic teams to take a large number of cuts to make up the
deficiency after the close of the athletic season.

X-PRESIDNT D. C. OILMAN has under preparation several articles for
Scribner's Magazine on his recollections of the last twenty-five years.
Dr. Gilman will treat of the advance in intellectual, educational, and
scientific knowledge, as it has come under his observation at Hopkins and
abroad. No one is more fitted to undertake such a series of recollections, and
their publication is awaited with much interest.

e

At the monthly meeting of the Trustees for November, the following
appointments were made: Rev. Theo. C. Foote, of Clinton, 0., to the W. S.
Rayner fellowship in Semitic languages; E. P. Hyde, of Baltimore, to the fellowship in physics; George O. Berg to the fellowship in Greek, succeeding Dr.
Roscoe Guernsey, who is made instructor in Latin; Dr. W. H. Lewis, of the
Medical School, to the instructorship in anatomy.
President Remsen reported that Mrs. Lucy J. Woods, of Jamaica Plains,
Mass., mother of Prof. R. W. Woods, had given $1,000 for the purpose of purchasing new and approved apparatus for the physical laboratory.
The University has received a notice of the Fifteenth Annual Convention
of the Association of Colleges and Preparatory Schools of the Middle States and
Maryland. The meeting will take place on November 29 and 30, at Syracuse
University, Many important subjects will be discussed, among them such
timely topics as the executive system in college courses, and the freedom of
speech to educators.
Dr. Harry T. Marshall, of the Medical School, has been selected for the
foreign fellowship of the Rockefeller Institute for Medical Research. The board
of directors, of which Dr. Welsh is president, decided at their last meeting in
New York that the income of the $200,000 fund was to be expended in maintaining 19 fellows, 18 of whom are to work in various American laboratories
and one abroad. Dr. Marshall is already at his post, which is Professor Ehrlich's laboratory in Germany. Each fellowship is for one year, during which
time the incumbent is to do original work and send his report to the Board,
with the view of having it published.
Dr. Richard T. Ely, director of the School of Economics and Political
Science, University of Wisconsin, who was associate professor of Political
Economy at Hopkins, 1887-92, has accepted an invitation to deliver the principal address at a meeting to commemorate the life and services of the late Dr.
Herbert B. Adams, The date of the meeting is uncertain.

The Johns Hopkins Hospital Historical Society held its first meeting for
the year on Monday night, November 11, in the Assembly Rooms of the
Hospital. Papers were read by Dr. John Turner, Jr., on "Ancient
Anatomists," and by Dr. E. F. Cordell on "The Medicine and Doctors of
Juvenal." Dr. Howard A. Kelly is the president of this Society.
Drs. Thomas McCrea and Guy L. Hunner, of the Hospital Medical Society
exhibited some interesting cases at a recent meeting at the Hospital.
The Major Biology Class had an exciting hunt for "Medusae," otherwise
known as jelly fish, last Tuesday. The members of this course heartily endorse this method of studying biology, even though no specimens are found.
The whole class, under the paternal care of Dr. Grave, who paid the carfare,
went to Fort McHenry, and there spent the afternoon in mild forms of recreation such as rowing heavy scows and grasping at imaginary medusae.
The inventory of the late Dr. Herbert B. Adams' personal estate showed
the amount to be $45,244.15, about $30.000 of which is in bonds. By his will,
Dr. Adams made the University residuary legatee of his estate. After various
bequests are made, the University will realize more than $30,000, which, by the
donor's request, will become a Herbert B. Adams Fund, the income to be
devoted to the advancement of history, political science, and education.
Mr. W. H. Buckler has presented to the University an autograph letter of
Benjamin Franklin, written from London to a friend in Florence. The letter
may be seen beneath the picture of Franklin in second floor of the physical
laboratory.
Dr. Geo. Dobbin Brown,Ph.D.in English and Literature last June, has been
appointed to temporarily fill the position of Dr. Tupper, professor of English
Literature in the University of Vermont. Professor Tupper is spending a year
in study at Berlin and Munich.
At the meeting of the Charity Organization Society, Monday of last week.
Dr. D. C. Gilman was elected president of the society. President Remsen and
Dr. Hollander were elected members of the board of governors.

STUDENT NOTES.
HE settee given to the trophy room by the class of 1901 has already shown
its value in bringing comfort to the University "loafing" room. Just
such a thing was needed to add some degree of warmth and coziness to
the room, which despite the hard seats, has always proved the best drawing
card in the University. Thanks are due the senior class for what is easily the
best thing so far given to the trophy-room, and on behalf of the class to the
committee which had such hard work selecting the gift. The committee consisted of J. R. Pels, chairman; G. Sisco, R. Sharretts, F. L. Guggenheimer, L.
C. Murphy.

THE NEWS-LETTER.

The Junior class is already considering the nature of their gift. Though
nothing definite has yet been decided upon, rumors are floating around in profusion. Everything, including leather upholstered arm chairs and a piano, has
been mentioned, with odds in favor of the chairs.
In the Senate, the ministry has failed, and Mr. S. Wolman, leader of the
opposition, is now in control of the government. The following administrative
officers have been chosen by Mr. Wolman to represent the opposition on the
floor; W. Kirk, Leader pro tem.; H. G. Dew, Secretary; Thomas C. Pinkerton,
Sergeant-at-Arms. Wednesday's debate was on the advisability of expelling all
anarchists from this country as the best means of eradicating anarchy.
The Musical Clubs have had their annual picture taken. As this year the
picture will be used on 1500 posters, extra care was employed to get a satisfactory group.

Y. M. C. A. NOTES.
HE Week of Prayer for young men was observed last week with daily
service in Levering Hall, from 1 to 1.20. Monday, Dr. Vincent spoke
on "The Reciprocal Relation of Learning to Religion;" Tuesday, Dr.
Greene, on "The Danger of Spiritual Neglect;" Wednesday, Dr. Henry Wood,
on "True Christian Realism;" Thursday, Dr. Brush, on "Honesty;" Friday,
Dr. Steiner, on "Overcoming."
The week of service was opened on Sunday by an inspiring address from
Rev. Oliver Huckel, on "Spiritual Realities."
The average attendance for the week was 25.
Mr. Robert E. Speer is expected to address a mass meeting of students on
Sunday, January 19th. Further notice will be given later.
The regular monthly meeting of the Executive Council was held Wednesday, November 13, at 5 P. M. About thirty new members were elected.
The State University of Iowa and McGill University are both campaigning
for Association buildings.

ATURDAY, November 9th, the Hopkins team covered itself with laurels
and caused many loyal hearts to beat faster, when she downed the Delaware College eleven in Wilmington by a score of 27 to 0. Too much
cannot be said in praise of the magnificent work done by the team as a whole
and by the individual players. And, add to this the fact that IIaverford, which
defeated our boys only a week previous in the hottest contest of the season by a
score of only 5 to 0, had been defeated by the Delaware lads earlier in the
season, every Hopkins "rooter" has just cause to be proud of the men who
wear the Black and Blue.
To be sure, Delaware was seriously weakened by the absence of Huxley,
their regular captain, and a few more of their men, but where were Garwood
and the other Hopkins men who had done so nobly in the Haverford game?
Everything taken into consideration, the teams were well matched both in
regard to weight and science, and all that our boys have achieved, they have
done on their own merits and to them all the praise is due.
For Hopkins, it would be difficult to single out one man who did more than
another for the success of the team. The backs played the game, and Gillespie
and Houghton went around the ends each time for a gain. Only twice during
the game was the oval in the possession of their opponents. For Delaware,
Lawton kicked well, and gained much time by the clever placing of the ball in
the second half; Cann, at right end, showed remarkable skill; Wilson did
excellent work back of the line, and Marshall, a new man, made several
beautiful tackles.
In the first half, after eight minutes of play, Gillespie circled the right end
for a touchdown, and in the remaining ten minutes of play, the 'varsity took a
brace, and before the referee's whistle blew, Sayler, Gillespie and Faris went
over the goal line for three more touchdowns.
Hopkins took the kick-off at the beginning of the game, and Blanck downed
the man after a short run. Lawton hit the line without effect, and Cooper went
around right end for eight yards. No more ground could be gained, and Cann

punted. Upon lining up, Sayler hit right tackle for five yards. Faris made a
plunge through the opposite tackle for 15 yards, and Gillespie and Houghton
made large gains on successive end-around-end runs.
The ball went steadily down the field, and Gillespie went around the end
for the first touchdown. Sayler failed to kick goal. On the second kick-off Bernheim caught the ball and made a pretty run before going down. Gillespie,
Faris, and Sayler made end runs of 12, 10 and 18 yards, repectively. End plays
by the backs and ends came off in quick succession, and Faris circled right end
for the second touchdown. Sayler did not kick goal.
On the next kick-off Blanck downed the ball, and the first play saw Faris
circle right end for eighteen yards. Houghton then showed his ability as a
sprinter. He was given the ball on the end-around-end play, and made a beautiful run of 40 yards. Gillespie again circled right end for 20 yards and a
touchdown. Sayler kicked goal.
On the line-up after the kick off, Gillespie repeated Houghton's trick by
rounding the opposite end for 40 yards. Sayler and Faris did not fail in a
single instance to make heavy gains through the line, and Sayler increased the
score to 22 points by hitting right tackle for a fourth touchdown. Only a few
more minutes of the half remained, but Blanck, Faris and Gillespie managed to
advance the ball about 32 yards before time was called.
In the second half, Delaware took a decided brace and the Hopkins men
were unable to secure more than one more touchdown. Lawton gained much time
by cleverly kicking the ball out of bounds each time it came into Delaware's possession. The game ended with the ball in Delaware's 35-yard line.

WESTERN MARYLAND, 0.

N a bard-fought contest, Saturday afternoon, IIopkins gave the annual
exhibition of beating Western Maryland. When the game started the
.
Westminster lads were confident that victory was theirs, and, indeed, for a
time the struggle was so fierce, that it seemed as if one team was as good as the
other, if not better.
. Western Maryland kicked off to Houghton, who advanced the ball to Hopkins 30 yard line. The Black and Blue now began to hammer their opponents'
line, and by fierce plunges through the opposite guards advanced the pigskin
15 yards. The Farmers now took a brace, and the line held like a stone wall,
so the ball went over. The Hopkinsonians in turn made a solid stand against
their opponents, and after a trifling gain by Western Maryland, again recovered
the oval, but lost it on a fumble.
.
The Westminster lads now tried some end runs, but in almost every
instance the runner was nailed in his tracks, so that the ball went over on downs.
Sayler was now sent around end for a gain of 10 yards, and Blanck in a similar

3

manner added 5 other yards hereto.
Western Maryland, still confident, however, allowed the Black and Blue to
make no further gains and the pigskins was lost on downs.
The Farmers slowly but steadily pushed the oval back over most of the
ground gained by Hopkins, but were interrupted by Sayler and Garwood, who
by brilliant tackling, caused Western Maryland to lose on downs.
The first half ended with the ball on Hopkins' 30 yard line, where Houghton
carried it on the kick-off, both teams having seesawed up and down in a space
of about 20 yards duringthe entire half.
In the second half, Sayler kicked off for Hopkins, and Western Maryland
brought the oval to her 25 yard line, and then failing to gain the required distance, punted. Hopkins now began to play ball in dead earnest; Blanck hit
the line for 7 yards, and Riggs followed with 8 more. Houghton now got
around the end at a beautiful rate, but strained his ankle, and was replaced by
Sharretts. Sayler again circled the ends for 20 yards, and Sharretts was shoved
through the line for an additional 8. The Black and Blue now had the ball
Within 5 yards of a touchdown, but there they stuck, and the oval was lost on
downs. Not discouraged by this, however, Hopkins soon forced her opponents
to kick, and with a beautiful end run of 20 yards by Sayler, the lost territory
was well nigh recovered. With two more line plunges, the pigskin rested on
the 3 yard line, and Riggs did the mark. Sayler then kicked a goal.
Western Maryland now kicked off and Hopkins began to pound the
Farmer's line a terrible rate, the latter being unable to hold together in any
Shape whatever. So by long gains through the line, and end runs, the Black
and Blue soon scored on her touchdown, failing to kick goal, however.
Western Maryland again kicked off, and Hopkins was well on her way to her
touchdown when time was called, with the ball on Western Maryland's 25 yard
line.

THE NEWS—LETTER.

Everyone is satisfied with the work of the team, and all are confident that
the same team can rub it into St. John's next Saturday. Garwood's work is
well nigh equal to that of Butler, whose style of play last year was so phenomenal. Sayler should he complimented for his effective work this season, especially in Saturday's game, and what Hill did to Western Maryland's star—
Roberts—was "enough." Coach Dickson remarked after the game, that the
fellows helped each other wonderfully. A little more practice in catching
punts, and we'll have a star team. The rooting, led by Grasty, was the best
heard this season, and the NEWS-LETTER hopes that all students in the
University will join the ranks next Saturday to cheer the Black and Blue on to
victory.

OUR SCRUB TEAM.

C

APTAIN GILLESPIE, of the 'varsity eleven, is to be congratulated for his
wisdom in appointing a captain of the scrub team, and Captain Winternitz also deserves a vote of thanks for the hearty manner in which he has
taken hold of matters and pushed his eleven forward. While the 'varsity was
administering a severe defeat to Delaware College last Saturday one week ago,
the scrubs were playing their first game against Dunham's Preparatory School.
Captain Winternitz had not yet completely organized the team, and the lack of
systematic play and unity lost the game by the score of 6 to 0. In the contest
against Marston's Preparatory School last Friday, however, the benefit of a
week's practice was plainly shown. For about five minutes in the first half,
Marston's held her own, and possibly a little more, but then the scrubs got
together, and from that moment on there was certainly "somethin' doin'."
Dickey, Pearre, and Plaggemeyer hit the line in great fashion, and little IIazlehurst toddled around the end for comfortable gains. Dickey made the star play
of the game, by catching the ball from the kick-off and running through the

J

THE NEWS—LETTER.

15

entire Marston eleven for a touchdown. Toward the end of the game the
scrubs worked together in great style, and it was this fast, concerted action
which gave them the victory by a score of 16 to 0. The work of several freshmen was conspicuous, and they promise to put up a hard fight when the annual
class game with the Juniors comes off. The scrubs usually line up as follows:
Hazlehurst, 1. e.; Riley, 1. t.; Erlanger, 1. g.; Marshall, c.; Ward, r. g.; Custis,
r. t.; Parsons, r. e.; Winternitz (captain) q. b.; Dickey, Pearre, 1. h. b.; Smith,
r. h. b.; Plaggerneyer, f. b.
The organization of a scrub team is a wise innovation in more ways than
one. In the first place, it adds strength and system to the team which is
depended upon to give the 'varsity practice; secondly, it brings out a great
many men who would not come out because of their inability to make the
'varsity; and thirdly, it arouses additional spirit among the freshmen, several
of whom are on the team. All these results tend to increase our chances of
winning the inter collegiate championship in the game with St. John's College
Saturday afternoon, It is every man's sacred duty to be on hand that day with
a strong pair of lungs in good working order.
